[[Broadmoor Skating Club]] |retired= |medaltemplates= {{MedalCountry| [[United States]]}} {{MedalSport | Pairs' [[Figure skating]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[Olympic Games]]}} {{MedalSilver | [[1952 Winter Olympics|1952 Oslo]] | [[Figure skating at the 1952 Winter Olympics|Pairs]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[World Figure Skating Championships|World Championships]]}} {{MedalSilver| [[1952 World Figure Skating Championships|1952 Paris]]|Pairs}} {{MedalSilver| [[1951 World Figure Skating Championships|1951 Milan]]|Pairs}} {{MedalGold| [[1950 World Figure Skating Championships|1950 London]]|Pairs}} {{MedalSilver| [[1949 World Figure Skating Championships|1949 Paris]]|Pairs}} {{MedalSilver| [[1947 World Figure Skating Championships|1947 Stockholm]]|Pairs}} {{MedalCompetition|[[North American Figure Skating Championships|North American Championships]]}} {{MedalGold| [[1951 North American Figure Skating Championships|1951 Calgary]]|Pairs}} {{MedalGold| [[1949 North American Figure Skating Championships|1949 Philadelphia]]|Pairs}} {{MedalBronze| [[1947 North American Figure Skating Championships|1947 Ottawa]]|Pairs}} }} {{MedalTop}} {{MedalSport | [[Figure skating]]}} {{MedalSilver | [[1952 Winter Olympics|1952 Oslo]] | Pairs}} {{MedalBottom}} '''Michael Edward "Peter" Kennedy III''' (born September 4, 1927 in [[Olympia, Washington]]) is an [[United States|American]] [[pair skater]]. Although named Michael, he was nicknamed Peter as a child, and has been credited in competition by both names. With his sister, [[Karol Kennedy|Karol]], he won five [[United States Figure Skating Championships|U.S. Championship]] titles from 1948-1952. Known as "The Kennedy Kids," they won the [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Championship]] in 1950, and the silver medal in the [[1952 Winter Olympics]]. ==Competitive highlights== (all with Karol) {| class="wikitable" !
